title: How to Bake Fish

steps.headline: Buy fish the same day you intend to make it.
steps.description: Fish tastes best when it's fresh, so plan a trip to the grocery store or fishmonger the same day you want to make it for dinner.

steps.headline: Choose healthy-looking fish.
steps.description: If you're buying a whole fish, look for fish with bright, clear eyes. Whether you're buying a whole fish or a fillet, the skin should look bright and vibrant.

steps.headline: Smell the fish before making a purchase.
steps.description: The fish shouldn't have a strong smell; it should smell like fresh seawater.

steps.headline: If possible, choose fish that was caught locally.
steps.description: Fish that has to travel long distances is often frozen and then thawed before reaching your grocery store. It may not taste as fresh as fish caught in your local body of water.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 275 °F (135 °C).
steps.description: Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil. Brush with olive oil.

steps.headline: Rinse the salmon fillets and pat them dry with paper towels.
Place the salmon fillets in the pan.
steps.description: Make sure they are skin side down.

steps.headline: Brush the fillets with olive oil.
steps.description: Squeeze lemon juice over the fillets.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the fillets with salt and fresh thyme.
Bake the fillets for about fifteen minutes.
steps.description: The fish is ready when the translucent flesh at its center has turned opaque. Be careful not to overcook the fish. Salmon gets tough and dry when it is overcooked. Test for doneness by gently separating a few layers of the salmon flesh with a fork. It should fall apart easily when it's fully cooked.

steps.headline: Serve the fillets with lemon wedges.
Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C).
steps.description: Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil. Brush with olive oil.

steps.headline: Rinse the tilapia fillets and pat them dry with paper towels.
Mix the bread crumbs, grated Parmesan, butter, and oil in a bowl.
Place the tilapia fillets in the baking pan.
steps.description: Sprinkle them liberally with the bread crumb mixture.

steps.headline: Bake the tilapia for about ten minutes.
steps.description: The fish is ready when the flesh has turned translucent and the topping is golden brown.

steps.headline: Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C).
steps.description: Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil. Brush with olive oil.

steps.headline: Rinse the fish.
steps.description: Take care to rinse out all of the cavities. Pat dry with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Cut the bottom back fin off the fish.
steps.description: Use a sharp knife to slice off the bottom fin, then run your knife along the bottom of the fish's belly from head to tail. This will open up the cavity to the oven's heat.

steps.headline: Place the fish in the baking pan.
steps.description: Drizzle the fish with olive oil, both on the outside of the fish and inside the cavity. Smooth it over the entire fish using your fingers.

steps.headline: Season the fish inside and out with salt and pepper.
Line the inside of the cavity with lemon slices.
steps.description: You should be able to fit four to five slices inside the fish, overlapping them slightly. Close the fish back up.

steps.headline: Bake the fish for thirty minutes.
steps.description: The fish is ready when the flesh inside has turned opaque and flaky, and the outside skin is crispy.

steps.headline: Serve the fish.
steps.description: Remove the skin and the fins. Cut each side of the fish in half and serve. Whole baked fish are often brought to the table whole before they are cut up for serving. Be sure your family or guests are aware that the fish still contains bones.

text: Choosing Fish Buy fish the same day you intend to make it. Fish tastes best when it's fresh, so plan a trip to the grocery store or fishmonger the same day you want to make it for dinner. Choose healthy-looking fish. If you're buying a whole fish, look for fish with bright, clear eyes. Whether you're buying a whole fish or a fillet, the skin should look bright and vibrant. Smell the fish before making a purchase. The fish shouldn't have a strong smell; it should smell like fresh seawater. If possible, choose fish that was caught locally. Fish that has to travel long distances is often frozen and then thawed before reaching your grocery store. It may not taste as fresh as fish caught in your local body of water. Low and Slow Baked Salmon Preheat the oven to 275 °F (135 °C). Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil. Brush with olive oil. Rinse the salmon fillets and pat them dry with paper towels.  Place the salmon fillets in the pan. Make sure they are skin side down. Brush the fillets with olive oil. Squeeze lemon juice over the fillets. Sprinkle the fillets with salt and fresh thyme.  Bake the fillets for about fifteen minutes. The fish is ready when the translucent flesh at its center has turned opaque. Be careful not to overcook the fish. Salmon gets tough and dry when it is overcooked. Test for doneness by gently separating a few layers of the salmon flesh with a fork. It should fall apart easily when it's fully cooked. Serve the fillets with lemon wedges.  Crispy Parmesan Tilapia Preheat the oven to 425 °F (218 °C). Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil. Brush with olive oil. Rinse the tilapia fillets and pat them dry with paper towels.  Mix the bread crumbs, grated Parmesan, butter, and oil in a bowl. Stir until thoroughly combined. Place the tilapia fillets in the baking pan. Sprinkle them liberally with the bread crumb mixture. Bake the tilapia for about ten minutes. The fish is ready when the flesh has turned translucent and the topping is golden brown. Whole Baked Fish Preheat the oven to 400 °F (204 °C). Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil. Brush with olive oil. Rinse the fish. Take care to rinse out all of the cavities. Pat dry with a paper towel. Cut the bottom back fin off the fish. Use a sharp knife to slice off the bottom fin, then run your knife along the bottom of the fish's belly from head to tail. This will open up the cavity to the oven's heat. Place the fish in the baking pan. Drizzle the fish with olive oil, both on the outside of the fish and inside the cavity. Smooth it over the entire fish using your fingers. Season the fish inside and out with salt and pepper.  Line the inside of the cavity with lemon slices. You should be able to fit four to five slices inside the fish, overlapping them slightly. Close the fish back up. Bake the fish for thirty minutes. The fish is ready when the flesh inside has turned opaque and flaky, and the outside skin is crispy. Serve the fish. Remove the skin and the fins. Cut each side of the fish in half and serve. Whole baked fish are often brought to the table whole before they are cut up for serving. Be sure your family or guests are aware that the fish still contains bones.

Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil.

Line a glass or metal baking pan with aluminum foil.
Brush with olive oil.
Rinse the fish.
Take care to rinse out all of the cavities.
Pat dry with a paper towel.
Cut the bottom back fin off the fish.
Use a sharp knife to slice off the bottom fin, then run your knife along the bottom of the fish's belly from head to tail.
This will open up the cavity to the oven's heat.
Place the fish in the baking pan.
Drizzle the fish with olive oil, both on the outside of the fish and inside the cavity.
Smooth it over the entire fish using your fingers.
Season the fish inside and out with salt and pepper.
Line the inside of the cavity with lemon slices.
You should be able to fit four to five slices inside the fish, overlapping them slightly.
Close the fish back up.
Bake the fish for thirty minutes.
The fish is ready when the flesh inside has turned opaque and flaky, and the outside skin is crispy.
Serve the fish.

Cut each side of the fish in half and serve.

Be sure your family or guests are aware that the fish still contains bones.
